head_line: EDITORIAL Millennials oppose Marcos burial at LNMB

array.sentence: Opinion  EDITORIAL Millennials oppose Marcos burial at LNMB  DISMISSING the wrong notion that they were to be blamed for the comeback of the Marcoses (i.e. voting for Bongbong Marcos), millennials or today’s youth have formally filed a petition before the Supreme Court to declare as unconstitutional Marcos Sr.’s planned burial at the Libingan ng mga Bayani.

    -> EDITORIAL/NN (compound)
  -> burial/NN (dobj)
    -> Marcos/NNP (compound)
  -> LNMB/NNP (nmod:at)

      -> notion/NN (dobj)

          -> that/IN (mark)
          -> they/PRP (nsubj)
          -> blamed/VBN (xcomp)
            -> to/TO (mark)
            -> be/VB (auxpass)
            -> comeback/NN (nmod:for)
              -> for/IN (case)
              -> the/DT (det)
              -> Marcoses/NNPS (nmod:of)
                -> of/IN (case)

        -> as/IN (case)
        -> Sr./NNP (nmod:poss)
          -> unconstitutional/JJ (amod)

array.sentence: To hear them speak more, we are reprinting herein the news dispatch regarding their filing of the petition against the planned burial.

array.sentence: To them, the elder Marcos “was a murderer, plunderer, and dictator.

array.sentence: Incidentally, we also have in this issue a news report about the students and faculty members of Ateneo de Naga University expressing their strong sentiment against the dictator’s planned burial in the hallowed ground reserved only for heroes.

array.sentence: Here’s the news dispatch that summarizes the salient points of the millennials’ 21-page petition filed before the Supreme Court:  Oftenly blamed for the return of the Marcoses into power, members of the youth collectively referred to as ‘millenials’ filed a petition for certiorari and prohibition before the Supreme Court Monday to prohibit the burial of former President Ferdinand Marcos Sr. at the Libingan ng mga Bayani (LNMB).

array.sentence: The petition asked the High Court to declare the Memorandum issued by the Secretary of the Department National Defense last August 7 and the interment of the deposed dictator at the LNMB as ultra vires for being without legal basis and unconstitutional.

array.sentence: Republic Act 289 stipulates that the power and authority to allow Marcos Sr. to be buried can only emanate from the Board of National Pantheon, of which Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana is not included.

    -> 289/CD (nummod)
  -> emanate/VB (ccomp)
    -> that/IN (mark)
    -> power/NN (nsubj)
      -> the/DT (det)
      -> and/CC (cc)
      -> authority/NN (conj:and)

        -> Sr./NNP (dobj)
          -> Marcos/NNP (compound)
        -> buried/VBN (xcomp)
          -> to/TO (mark)
          -> be/VB (auxpass)
    -> authority/NN (nsubj)
    -> can/MD (aux)
    -> only/RB (advmod)
    -> Board/NNP (nmod:from)
      -> from/IN (case)

array.sentence: They also argued that the deposed dictator is disqualified from being buried at the 103-hectare Heroes’ Cemetery for he falls under the category of those ‘dishonorably separated or discharged from the service’ and was witnessed by the whole world on February 25, 1986 and that a LNMB burial for Marcos Sr. would place him in the same category as other Presidents who are already buried in the LNMB – Presidents Elpidio Quirino, Carlos Garcia, and Diosdado Macapagal, all of which were not ousted from office or found to be guilty of atrocities and ill-gotten wealth.

No. 10368 or the Human Rights Victims Reparation and Recognition Act of 2013.

array.sentence: Meanwhile Lim, also a petitioner against the curfew ordinances of the cities of Manila, Quezon and Navotas said, “May this petition symbolize our eternal gratefulness to the freedom fighters of the previous generation by their unspeakable sacrifices and collective struggle we millenials enjoy what was denied of them in their youth”.
